{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3634123,"name":"Nicholas Armstrong","username":"narmstro","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/5e9695/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-05-23T11:18:54.397Z","cooked":"

This is going to live in the world of somewhat silly and somewhat serious.

k_v is the feedforward constant in V = k_s * sgn(v) + k_v * v + k_a * a

k_V is a very common back emf constants used in the following motor equation.

V = IR + (1/k_V) omega. Also from what I can tell k_V is equal to k_V. (They have the same units). In SI radians/second/V

Most of the vendors and ReCalc determine/provide this value.

I’ve also seen much of the literature on DC motor equations us k_e (V / rad/s) in the form
V = IR + k_e omega. This is just the reciprocal of k_V.

Also I’m aware that k_t (the motor torque constant) (Nm /A) is identical in value (or should be) but not units (though they are dimensionally equivalent).

Wpilib’s DCMotor class uses nominal voltage, free speed, resistance, and free current to determine k_V.

I’m really just wondering (this is the silly/serious part) why use k_V when it can be easily mistaken for k_v (though they somewhat feel the same) when k_e can be used which makes the motor equation cleaner and easier to derive the value of.
V = IR + k_e omega.
